channel.title: biomechanics on Ross Wilkinson
channel.description: Recent content in biomechanics on Ross Wilkinson

item.title: Cycling in a non-seated position reduces the mechanical requirements of the knee joint
Mechanical energetics relating to rider centre of mass motion during non-seated cycling
Sit, stand, rock and roll: towards optimal pedalling posture
PhD Thesis
item.description: THE EFFECT OF LATERAL BICYCLE SWAY AND RIDING POSTURE ON MECHANICAL EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY IN CYCLING Cyclists often spontaneously switch from a seated to non-seated position when they need to produce high pedal torque and power (i.e. during steep climbs, accelerations and sprinting). Existing evidence shows that adopting a non-seated position can improve uphill time trial performance and increase peak power output during sprint cycling, yet the mechanisms underpinning these performance advantages remain unclear.
